comments.commentBody:
Joel, Take a well-deserved vowel, you did good!

Howie TBOQ

Thinker:  best post of the day and spot on.  What's even more pathetic than Obama's vocal and military support (Libya) for these new radical theocracies is the US taxdollars he threw at the jihadists the first week they came to power.  $2 Billion for Tunisia, and an extra $2 Billion for the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt.  He still won't tell us how much the Libyan war (sorry, "kinetic action" cost us or how much aid we're giving the jihadists).

I'm very glad that you were helped but why  do you think the most important factor was that the leaders were also people in recovery from eating disorders, as opposed to their having been trained in C.B.T. and mindfulness, which is a form of D.B.T. ? I used to think as you did. After decades of being "treated "by therapists who were supposedly recovered from eating disorders, I have been helped far more with an eating disorder encompasses Binge Eating, Anorexia , and Bulimia, by a psychologist who is a specialist in C.B.T . who does not have a history of disordered eating,  His  naturally relaxed , uncomplicated relationship with food and eating, as well as his substantial skill as a C.B.T. therapist,  have been a  big part of my recovery.

Over several years of practicing yoga in the classroom I began to experience injuries and pain with increasing frequency.  Because of my touchy knees there were more poses I couldn't do (hero) or could only do by customizing (pigeon on my back).   My slight scoliosis made backbends and inversions painful.  I finally left the classroom but continued to modify and practice on my own.   By holding on to a prop I could go much more deeply into an asana without fearing I would lose my balance and jerkily fall out of the pose (this was how I injured myself several times in class).  I could practice balance more efficiently and with greater concentration on my own and not while also straining to stretch or hold.  Yoga has much to teach us but we need to customize it to meet our individual needs -- and often that requires a solitary practice.   I was sorry to leave the classes and the Lululemon crowd behind but my strength, balance, and flexibility is now better than when I left.

Just curious, did your doctor at any time ever check your thyroid or other hormones to see if there was, perhaps, an imbalance? That should have been the next step or at least there should have been a further evaluation to determine if there was some other underlying health issue, particularly as you were eating 1200 calories a day for 16 months, along with all the cardio and strength training, and still not seeing any results.

You didn't lose any weight by eating 1200 calories a day and exercising, because it's not so much about calories but about the kind of food you're eating. Eating animal products and processed/refined foods, even just 1200 calories worth of them, fosters certain kinds of digestive bacteria in our gut that cause obesity.

If you were eating just some brown rice with lots of vegetables and greens, plus raw nuts and fresh fruit for snacking, and drank a lot of water, there is no way your extra weight would not disappear. Most importantly, such a diet would create a community of beneficial bacteria in your gut that would change/improve your metabolism and help you stay thin even while occasionally indulging in something tasty as a treat.

This may sound odd- but for your height and current weight AND fitness level, 1200 calories is probably too low.  I know it sounds counter-intuitive but increase your calorie amount to be above your BMR - basal metabolic rate or the amount your body burns if you sat around and did nothing - and below your TDII (you can google BMR and TDII to understand more).   I bet you should be eating somewhere between 1500-1800 calories daily.  You may gain a pound or two for the first four weeks but after awhile your body will stop feeling like it is in starvation mode from your constant working out and your metabolism may improve.

The last time I was told to lose weight, I whipped out my food diary and exercise journal for the prior 8 months and said, "What do I do differently?" Eight months of 1200 calories a day maximum, 60 minutes of high impact cardio 5 days a week, and weight lifting 4 days a week...and I didn't lose a pound. My doctor had no suggestions except to keep at it. I did for about 16 months before my husband and mother finally persuaded me to stop. I still hadn't lost any weight at all. But, I had constant gastrointestinal issues, problems sleeping and depression. And, this is the "healthy" lifestyle?

At 5'6" and 165, I'm definitely overweight and borderline obese. But, so far, the medical community has offered me no answers or solutions. It's not about whether my doctor is fat or thin. It's about whether he can help me. It's pretty obvious that he can't because he doesn't know how. The only thing that anyone seems to have is "calories in, calories out" and I know that doesn't work.

In epidemiology, including in these studies, you "weed out" those factors by controlling for confounders, among other techniques.

For China studies, please see the links I posted below.

I don't know if it's possible to have a study to see if this is true.  There are too many extraneous factors to weed out.  For examples, those who live in polluted areas are usually poorer, have higher rate of smoking, and perhaps poor eating habits.  How can you weed these out to make sense and see if it's actually the air pollution that causing the heart disease?  I'm not sure it's possible. How about China?  We all know how rotten the air pollution is there.  Is heart disease rate increasing there?

Are you kidding?! A doc certainly can't control (for either the better - or the worse) the lifestyle choices of his/her staff.  We can't  - and shouldn't - hire based on the slim/toned physiques (or lack thereof) of our PA and MA applicants.  Some of the PAs/MAs in my office drink a veggie juice and go on a power walk at 45minute lunch break; others eat a BigMac and gossip.  It's their time and their personal choice.

I finished a top 5 medical school and served on the admission committee in the 1980s. I was on the campus and in affiliated hospitals for 9 years through medical school, research, and residency and had an opportunity to see some immediate and now long-term [albeit anecdotal] outcomes.

Even then, the medical school did not admit strictly on the basis of GPAs and MCAT scores (Rhode Scholars were rejected) as there was a stated priority to graduate a third of the class as “academician, researchers, AND healthcare leaders.” Over the years, I had roommates and classmates whose non-science undergraduate majors included nutrition (Cornell), Spanish (Amherst), French (Princeton), History (Stanford) and others. All were very smart and performed very well. Some who came as science majors left as physician executives.

Students who were often admitted with the highest GPAs and MCAT scores were not necessarily the ones who performed best during the clinical years or the ones who have had career positions in healthcare leadership.

It is noteworthy that the new MCAT for 2015 and beyond will have two new sections: behavior and social science (psychology), and critical analysis and reasoning (on passages from a wide range of social science and humanities disciplines). I think we are moving in the right direction.
If advice made one thin then I would be invisible
I can think of few better ways to do work that matters than to share your precious gift of giving voice to thoughts and fears that few of us can conceive let alone express so eloquently.

In 1963, when I was in high school, I read a Time mag article about teratomas, a term I've never forgotten. In the story, it said it was a twin that had never properly developed. No one in my homeroom class believed me. My dad had thrown away the magazine, so I went to the library, went thru half a dozen magazines, found it, checked it out, brought it to homeroom and - voila - there was the proof I needed. The class was dumbfounded and I was vindicated.
Hopefully you're seeing an opthamologist and not an optometrist for surgery.

"Lifestyle changes work 100% of the time because you have to tackle the root of the problem or else you will fail..."

Ah yes, more of the vaunted "common sense" that serves us so well.

Yes, if you do whatever it takes, no matter how difficult or seemingly impossible it may be for you, you will succeed 100% of time, guaranteed. Not just for weight loss, for anything...even becoming a billionaire or the President of the US. Because if you succeed, then by definition you did what it took and correspondingly, if you fail you didn't do what it took.

The problem is that it's circular logic; a tautology that means nothing.

We are still faced with the fact that the standard advice of diet and exercise for the overweight or obese fails somewhere between 90-98% of the time. And clearly, many more people are becoming obese and facing these dismal odds. Maybe it is, as so many seem to want to believe, just a matter that people are just more and more willfully gluttonous/slothful over the past 30 years; even though there is a lot of evidence that rebuts this. Even so, it's still an inadequate answer...you have to ask yourself, why on earth would this be?

But then, it's a nice easy answer to just say obesity it's a moral/psychological failing and if the obese tried harder at "lifestyle changes" they'd lose weight. Of course, we can say the same thing about failing to be in the top 2% in wealth as well.

I'm not surprised the woman having annual pap tests had "treatment" for "dysplasia" ...most women having annual pap tests will end up having a false positive and over-treatment. The lifetime risk of referral for colposcopy/biopsy with 2 yearly screening from teens is a whopping 77% here in Australia, with annual testing, the referral rate would be even higher.
Note: the lifetime risk of cervical cancer is 0.65%...so almost all of these "treatments" amount to over-treatment. Sadly, over-treatment convinces many women they were "saved" so they continue to overdo pap tests. It also, leads women to see cervix cancer as a far greater threat than it actually is...thyroid cancer affects more people, but there is nowhere near the same fuss made about it. Our perception of risk has been skewed.
I believe women have been trained to greatly fear a rare cancer and that's unfair and can lead women to ignore far greater risks to their health. The No 1 killers are shoved into the background.

This is complete nonsense. How is Onamacare, providing people with health insurance they did not have before, responsible for people preferring to go to emergency rooms when their doctor is not immediately available?

Insightful article that shows how emergency rooms are being used in a manner that costs taxpayers a significant amount of money.  Unfortunately, this problem will only become worse with the new Obama Care that will go into place in 2014.  This will provide more people with health insurance but many will go to the emergency room instead of seeking out a primary care physician.  These actions will continue to drive the cost of health care up and reduce access to those patients that need an emergency physician.  This will create outcomes that are poor and increase the risk of adverse conditions for many patients.  The use of emergency rooms will need to be addressed in the near future otherwise we will see hospitals close the emergency room doors.

Oh boy, are you telling me that Americans have to pass background checks to collect food stamps or other federal benefits?  But why am I surprised anyway?  Since when is being poor or unemployed grounds for reasonable suspicion of having committed a crime?   The US just keeps getting more and more backward.  Having my Japanese wife divorce me four years ago this June nearly killed me, but I'm becoming more and more convinced that my son might just be better off here anyway.   I'm not a fan of the way they do everything in groups here, but he sure looked happy when I went to watch his swimming lesson yesterday.

To 10 Obesity Myths (from 2009, but still worth a look)

http://www.britannica.com/blogs/2009/12/top-10-obesity-myths/

Here's a sampling of the list (details & explanations at the link).

Myth #1: Overweight people are all at great risk of weight-related death.
Myth #2: Obesity is about to surpass smoking as the number one cause of preventable deaths in this country. (No, the CDC goofed by 94%. NINETY-FOUR! Oops! Sorry, America!)
Myth #4: Being fat is worse for your health than being thin.
Myth #5: You cannot be both overweight and healthy.

I've been dancing at the same gym and with the same people for about four years. While I happen to be skinny, there are people in the classes who I'm certain fall into the at least the lower end of the obese BMI category, and THEY ARE FIT, and beautiful dancers too. Skinny does not mean healthy. Fat does not mean bad health.

Moreover, I want my doctors to be brilliant, number one, still learning in their fields and listening to their patients, numbers two and three. Self care...not so high on my list.

Elizabeth- frequency of Pap smears is one thing. They are probably not necessary under the age of 30, and q2-3 years is O.K after that. The Finnish experience you quote of 6-7 Paps in a lifetime makes me nervous because a single Pap smear is only 50% sensitive, but I'll take your word for it that the Finnish screening program is effective.

However, you admit you have never had ONE Pap smear.

Assuming you have ever been heterosexually active , that is a very bad idea. If you have convinced one woman reading this thread not to have any Pap smears, you have done them a serious disservice.

Don't confuse apples and oranges, in this case Pap smears and other screening tests. And don't assume you are always correct in your interpretation of medical data.

A little knowledge can be a dangerous thing. Sorry to offend you, but as a medical professional active in the field, I feel I had to comment

Pap smears save lives. Lets hope that your vigorous criticisms don't cost any.

I suppose many over weight physicians get just as discouraged as most people by many conflicting approaches to weight loss.

For years, I flunked attempts to lose weight. I could not sustain the effort needed to calculate and record calories consumed. And the many "low calorie" TV dinners I ate did not really feel particularly nourishing and just left me feeling hungry. The turning point came when I read "The China Study" by T. Colin Campbell, which gave me a wider view of why the, so-called, Standard American Diet contributes so pervasively to obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and many other chronic ailments, and why a largely plant- based diet is so supportive of good health.

I can never be a vegan. However, I found that it's not so very hard to do more home cooking and to to eat categories of food which have higher micro-nutrient density per calorie and higher volume per calorie (makes you feel full) - which end up being mostly whole plant foods. I still eat limited amounts of non-dairy products, turkey, chicken and fish or oil, a bit of blue cheese, and some dark chocolate, and just occasional sweets.

Instead of sodas, I add fresh or frozen fruit (no sugar added) to a glass of cold water, then lightly freeze it a few minutes. I like Stevia sweetener and Spike no salt seasoning. I've lost my excess weight and got off all meds.

I suggest - Google- "Phytochemicals and ANDI food score" and

YouTube "Dean Ornish, MD - Transform 2010 - Mayo Clinic
At the expense of poisoning the water table and releasing radioactive materials into the waste water which cannot be chemically treated and made "safe".
I am waiting for Hipple-Von Lindau disease to show up. Or is it Von Hipple-Lindau? My personal favorite, and I actually saw one.

Why do animals stretch? Dogs, birds, cats, for example, all stretch.

Have they read a study that says stretching is good for them?

I had doctors nag me about being 20 lbs over weight. Then I had to gain 20 to 30 lbs in 6 weeks to survive cancer radiation treatment. I was too tiny.

So now I have a big belly that I hate-but I'm alive and healthy. If a doctor starts complaining, I pull out my oncologists's business card, and I tell the Dr. to talk to my oncologist about it.

My MD is my MD not my friend. He treats me with respect as a patient. I expect him to tell me the truth but with kindness and empathy which he does. I am overweight and we have discussed it on many occasions but he doesn't hit me over the head with it. I have mirrors. Often people go from MD to MD until they hear what they want to hear, not what they need. My MD tells me the truth but in a nice way.
You must have never seen the TV show, House MD.  Based on Hugh Laurie's realistic depiction, it is clear that a physician can be both a drug addicts and a world class clinician.  Duh!
